Body:
I'm trying to create a product where customers have remote Raspberry Pi computers. These computers should be able to submit captured images and metadata to cloud file storage once a day (e.g., Google Cloud Storage)

How would you organize such system in terms of security, key storage, protocols, etc?

I reviewed Google Cloud IOT, but this solution seems to be an overkill. maybe I'm wrong. Also, seems like passing images via such solution is too expensive. but I like the part of device management and software upgrades. Is it better to use Google Cloud IOT or Amazon IOT or try to develop a more simple solution on my own?

Cloud IoT (Google's or Amazon's) is going to be overkill for what you're talking about.

Google Cloud Storage has APIs (pick your language
column15: Python and Ruby). Since you're using Raspberry Pi
column16:
they can run these APIs directly. Setup a cron job to run your script to push whatever you want into a storage bucket.

You'll need to setup an account on Google Cloud Platform to use the APIs. There's very good quickstart guides on this here.

"

Body: If you want to go ahead and use Google Cloud IoT, you can try the Cloud IoT Core API, there is a good tutorial for it here. As indicated in the quickstart
column9:
I would recommend using Node.js for this API.

After that
column10: you can integrate this API with Cloud Storage or another storage product that you see fit (Datastore
column12: etc.). As it was said before
column13:
you can setup a cron job for the storage operations.

"
